attributes.action: Reject any future applications to increase passenger numbers at Luton Airport
attributes.background: Luton Council are consulting on increasing passenger numbers from 18 to 32million per year as a preliminary step for an application for a Development Consent Order (DCO). We call upon the UK Government to refuse any future application to increase the number of passengers using London Luton Airport.
attributes.additional_details:
This expansion of airport capacity is surely contrary to the recommendations of the Committee on Climate Change.

The airport (LLA) doubled its capacity between 2014 and 2019, creating immense strain on local transport infrastructure, unbearable noise impacts on neighbouring communities and increased greenhouse gas emissions.

Now LLA wants to almost double its capacity from 18 million passengers a year to 32 million, despite the Climate Emergency and the impact the increase in flights will surely have on the environment.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Protect the UK’s countryside and coast from post-lockdown damage
attributes.background: The Government should fund nationwide and sustained countryside public behaviour messaging and education including: messaging ahead of the current lockdown ending, an ongoing campaign directed at staycationers, and a sustained education initiative, thus creating a lasting legacy.
attributes.additional_details:
Remember the almost daily news headlines and images of how our natural beauty spots were being abused?

The 2020 hit-and-run approach for holidays had a serious, negative effect on the countryside and coastline with mass littering, fly-camping, graffiti and fire being caused by visitors simply unaware of the impact they were having. We earnestly do not want a repeat of this for the upcoming season as delicate environments cannot sustain the level of degradation they received last year.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Scrap RIS2 (Road Investment Strategy 2)
attributes.background: In the middle of a climate emergency, we shouldn't be building and upgrading 4,000 miles of new roads. Roads produce very high amounts of carbon emissions. We need to invest less in more polluting roads and more in other greener modes of transport like rail.
attributes.additional_details: Even with electric vehicles, roads still cause high emissions and damage the environment both to build and while they're in use. E.g. tyre particulates have been found to damage the environment. The use of electric vehicles shouldn't be used as an argument to carry on building roads in this fashion.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban the Advertising of Meat Products
attributes.background: Ban or restrict advertising in the media of products containing meat such as beef, pork, poultry and fish in order to reduce the demand for and consumption of meat and animal products. Reducing our meat consumption as a nation will benefit public health and our environment.
attributes.additional_details: A recent UN report has said that lesser consumption of animal products is crucial to save the world from the worst impacts of climate change. Livestock and their byproducts contribute to greenhouse gas emissions and have been associated with risks of disease spreading. Eating meat has been shown to increase risk of heart disease, cancer, strokes and obesity. Reducing our meat consumption as a nation will benefit public health and our environment.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Ban new incinerator and pyrolysis sites and invest in waste reduction
attributes.background: We want the government to follow the example set in the EU by banning any new incinerators for the purpose of waste disposal. They should also ban pyrolysis facilities, and instead seek the solutions we need to reduce waste completely by investing in waste reduction, reuse and recycling.
attributes.additional_details:
Unfortunately waste management companies are benefitting from not having to pay similar taxes to that which are imposed on land-fill.

Communities across the breadth of the UK have campaigned against waste incinerators as many do not want one in their town or city.

The reasons for this are clear:

1) Incinerators risk harm to the health of local residents
2) Incinerators can pollute the air with toxic emissions
3) Incinerator emissions contribute to global warming
4) Incinerators can harm the environment

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Change law to mean that if an adult discovers a dead body it must be reported
attributes.background: At the moment, if a person finds the body of someone deceased, they are under no obligation to report this to the police. This means a body could be left for days, weeks etc. and remain undiscovered.
attributes.additional_details: I think this should already be law, and even if it’s in a home environment this does not need to be reported as per the law right now.

departments.name: Ministry of Justice

attributes.action: Protect the Environment – support carbon neutral energy alternatives
attributes.background:
In November 2019, Members of the UK Youth Parliament, sitting in the House of Commons voted “Protect the Environment” as its campaigning priority for this year.

We are calling for the Government to ban fracking, end the mining of fossil fuels and instead support carbon neutral energy alternatives.
attributes.additional_details:
To preserve this world for the next generation, we have a moral responsibility to protect it from the effects of Climate Change. Climate change is a problem than will affect young people more than any other generation.

Right now, the Government are not protecting the environment in the way that is necessary for young people and the next generation.

http://www.ukyouthparliament.org.uk/2019/news/climate-emergency-declared-biggest-issue-facing-young-people/

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Increase subsidies for growing fruit, vegetables, nuts, seeds, legumes, etc
attributes.background: The Government should increase subsidies for farmers to grow healthy foods such as fruit, vegetables, legumes, grains, nut and seeds which have no saturated fat. This should help increase availability of this produce and so encourage greater public health and ease the pressure on the NHS
attributes.additional_details:
The NHS says that eating too much saturated fats in your diet and that as part of a healthy diet, people should try to cut down on foods and drinks that are high in saturated fats .
 
If farmers can be encouraged through subsidies to grow healthy fruit, vegetables, nuts, seeds, legumes etc. then over time this should result in more uptake of healthy eating at lower cost to the consumer with all the attendant advantages to the environment and of course the NHS.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Require developers felling trees to fund reforestation projects
attributes.background:
Tree growth is an effective means of trapping carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas. The UK has one of the lowest forested areas in Europe.

Mature trees are lost in housing and infrastructure development.

We want Parliament to legislate to ensure these trees are adequately replaced.
attributes.additional_details:
New forests absorb carbon dioxide, help biodiversity and help the UK to meet its carbon footprint target.

At present, a mature tree lost in the course of a development is replaced, if at all, by a sapling on site. The net loss of carbon trapping is detrimental to the local environment and the atmosphere.

There would be a formula whereby the funding for replacement saplings depends on the size of the tree lost. 

The national and global benefits of more forestation will accrue wherever it is done.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban plastic packaging for fruit and vegetables
attributes.background: France and Spain have recently pledged to ban plastic packaging for fruit and vegetables from January 2022. We want the UK Government to follow suit and reduce unnecessary plastic waste.
attributes.additional_details: Plastic waste does not biodegrade. It gets into the environment, into the oceans and can cause injury or death to animals. Even if recycled properly, plastic packaging needs to be managed by the local council. Reducing the amount we purchase would reduce this burden and save taxpayers money. Fruit and veg is often transported long distances without plastic and packaged for sale to enhance presentation. It is not needed to protect the fruit.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Fund support schemes for survivors of Child Sex Abuse
attributes.background: I know first-hand how difficult it was to be heard, and how uncomfortable it was for me to speak up in my professional environment. Labelled a failure and the girl going nowhere, I was absolutely held back by the stigma attached to my life, that I hid for years - ashamed of what had happened to me.
attributes.additional_details:
For many, the resultant mental trauma from child sex abuse is like being in prison. Because of this many survivors don't have the ability to apply for jobs, work or find any success. Talented survivors circle around a life of silence & fear because they are ashamed of what has happened to them.

By allowing this conversation some air we can create increased productivity and success for the many survivors suffering in silence.
 
The Government must fund specialist schemes to provide more support for survivors than is currently available, including support for people to get into and return to work.

departments.name: Home Office

attributes.action: Seek to secure international ban on fracking at COP26
attributes.background: UK government announced a moratorium on fracking at start of the 2019 election campaign but left the door open to new applications to frack (unconventionally drill) in the future. We're calling on the Government to seek to agree an international, legally enforceable BAN on fracking as part of COP26.
attributes.additional_details: Residents who have campaigned to have fracking prevented in their communities, have no sense of safety and security whilst fracking is under a moratorium; we call for a legal ban on unconventional energy extraction that can put lives, health, the environment and climate at risk.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Protect Jones’ Hill Wood from being destroyed by HS2
attributes.background: Stop Jones’ Hill Wood from being destroyed due to HS2 development. Leave this beautiful, ancient woodland alone.
attributes.additional_details: Jones’ Hill Wood is a beautiful woodland area that inspired Roald Dahl to write ‘Fantastic Mr. Fox’. Not only is it a part of history but also a home for wildlife and a stunning place that people can visit. It allows for people to be educated on nature and offers them a stunning environment to enjoy.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Require the NHS to provide single-sex psychiatric wards including intake wards
attributes.background:
Psychiatric wards are often mixed-sex. Patients can be unable to get food, drink, medication, see visitors or doctors without passing through or using mixed-sex areas.

Bathrooms and dormitories are single sex but staff are not always present; sexual assaults are not uncommon on mixed-sex wards.
attributes.additional_details: Mixed-sex wards can feel as if they lack privacy and at times can feel unsafe. Some patients have a history of abuse and trauma and need a single-sex environment to heal. The Government should require the NHS provide single-sex psychiatric wards so that this is possible.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Ban the sale of manual plastic toothbrushes in the UK by 2025.
attributes.background: We would like the UK Government to ban the sale of manual plastic toothbrushes in the UK by 2025. Manual plastic toothbrushes are a notorious example of harmful plastic waste, and there are a variety of environmentally friendly alternatives in the market to move forward with.
attributes.additional_details: In the UK alone, 264 million manual plastic toothbrushes are thrown out every year. Each one of these plastic toothbrushes is non-biodegradable, meaning they'll last in the environment for over 600 years causing damage to wildlife and littering our country. There are already a variety of green alternatives available today, like bamboo toothbrushes which are readily biodegradable. Toothbrushes do not need to be harmful to the environment, so let's ban manual plastic ones.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Amend the Procurement Bill to enshrine positive environmental obligations.
attributes.background: The Procurement Bill should create a legal obligation on Contracting Authorities ensuring all specifications and contractors have a net positive impact upon the environment and that this requirement is designed into the procurement and management of public spend for all goods, services and works.
attributes.additional_details: Climate change is an existential threat to every UK citizen and future generations. The Public Sector spends £300B per annum, taxpayers’ money should be spent to prevent negative climate impact and encourage positive climate solutions and innovation. Creating a legal obligation to incorporate net positive environmental considerations supports Governments strategy of being a world leader in climate change, its COP26 and broader climate obligations, while encouraging economic growth.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Ban Jetskis from coastal waters and inland waterways
attributes.background: Jetskis are a hazard to wildlife and the natural environment, often being driven too fast for wildlife and people to respond and get out of their way. Users sometimes harass and chase wildlife, they are often unable to see some flora and fauna which lies just below the surface.
attributes.additional_details: Our wildlife is in crisis and we must respond quickly.  There have been promises of more protection and reversing declines. Jetskis are designed for speed and thrills and in many cases are used in fairly shallow waters. They are not compatible with the protection of our marine environment in coastal waters and inland waterways.  Important flora and fauna can be harmed and disturbed by these speeding motorised water craft. Swimmers and divers can also be at risk of harm. We need an outright ban

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Fund appropriate support for children with Speech & Communication Disorders.
attributes.background: Conduct an urgent review of Speech & Language Therapy focusing on: ensuring therapy is provided face to face in a Covid safe environment within 6 months of referral; Insisting children receive a formal diagnosis; providing continuous therapy without being forced to constantly re-apply
attributes.additional_details: Before Covid-19, children with Speech & Communication Disorders often waited several years for therapy. During lockdown, it was removed, and despite returning to school, children are still been denied face to face sessions. Many are being told they may be discharged and have to re-apply, and are being denied receiving a formal diagnosis. Communication between SLT and schools is inadequate. Children deserve a proper level of support, in the same way we would expect for other medical conditions.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Immediately end all animal agriculture subsidies in the UK
attributes.background: The UK Government allocates around £3 billion per year in subsidies to agricultural industries, £700m of which subsidises animal factory farming.
attributes.additional_details: Factory farming is responsible for animal mutilation, hormone injections, cramped living conditions and slaughter. It harms our planet and our natural eco-systems. Even non-intensive animal agriculture is still cruel and bad for the environment.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase student maintenance loans in line with inflation on a yearly basis
attributes.background: In the current economic climate, it is vital to increase student maintenance loans alongside the rate of inflation on a yearly basis.
attributes.additional_details: With the cost of rent for students soaring, many will find themselves to get by in the coming academic years. It is essential we support our future generation’s learning environment by ensuring they feel financially secure and able to continue with their studies.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Require mobile phones sold in the UK to be repairable by consumers
attributes.background:
Phone manufacturers have programmed it to be impossible for people to repair devices, even with genuine parts recovered from other devices.
 
We need to protect the environment, small businesses, and consumer rights. 7.1m iPhones were sold last year.
attributes.additional_details:
A poll in 2018 found 53% of participating Brits had smartphones repaired that year.

Many of the latest phones are seemingly impossible to repair on the open market. This is environmentally harmful, and anti-consumer. The government says it wants to 'Build Back Greener'. Reducing avoidable waste is an achievable major step.
 
https://finder.com/uk/iphone-sales-statistics
https://www.independent.co.uk/a8536236.html

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Work with the French Government, to protect/save international rail travel.
attributes.background:
Explore options, and/or work with the French Government, to protect/save international rail travel.

We're asking you to consider exploring support options along with the French government to protect international rail travel, in a similar way to that given to the UK's rail and Airline companies.
attributes.additional_details:
Due to the Covid-19 pandemic Eurostar International are in a dire financial situation, which could risk the future of international rail travel. Services are been cut to the minimum of one per day, staff have been made redundant, stations have been closed etc. The possibility of the end of high speed international travel now seems very real.

Eurostar, for example, offer a unique alternative to international travel, which creates thousands of jobs and is better for the environment. HS1 is due to become the first UK railway to be powered by renewable energy, there is a great future for Eurostar, for all of us, if Eurostar International and international rail travel in general can survive this. Thank you.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Increase Statutory Maternity Pay in line a 40 hours week on minimum wage
attributes.background: Statutory Maternity Pay (SMP) is currently set at £151. 20 a week, which is not enough to meet the cost of life in the UK and the added costs of providing for a baby, especially for families on low incomes. Government should increase SMP to allow all children to have the best start in life.
attributes.additional_details: The early years are a vulnerable time when children’s experiences and environments can negatively influence their development. Growing up in poverty has a long lasting impact on children's development, school attainment and health. Children in more deprived areas are more likely to face a serious illness during childhood and to have a long-term disability. The current SMP puts an added strain on single mothers and families on low incomes and negatively affects the life of their children.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Prohibit the sale and use in the UK of palm oil and its derivatives in foods
attributes.background: We call on the Government, now a study has established that palmitic acid, a constituent of palm oil, can encourage the spread of some cancers, to end the sale and use of palm oil in Britain.
attributes.additional_details:
Palm oil is used in an extremely wide range of processed foods. It is currently difficult to avoid, yet recent research has shown that it could exacerbate the growth of some cancers.
 
It is not acceptable that people should have their health and lives put at risk by food corporations that put profits before people and environment.
 
https://www.worldwidecancerresearch.org/news-opinion/2021/november/how-dietary-fats-help-cancer-to-spread-around-the-body/

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Fund plastic recycling processing plants and ban export of plastic waste
attributes.background: Plastic waste processing plants should be built across the UK. Plastic waste should be processed in a way to minimize environmental harm. Within three years the export of plastic waste should be banned.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK’s approach to plastic recycling is a sham and the environmental harm being caused is immoral. 

As seen on TV, much of the UK’s plastic waste is being exported to places like Turkey and Asia, where much of the waste is burned, poisoning the environment. 

If the UK builds sufficient plastic waste processing plants, we can take responsibility for our own waste, and stop exporting our problem. 

This will create jobs, reduce environmental harm, and improve the UK’s international reputation.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Create statutory procedures for sexual offence complaints at university
attributes.background: The Government should require investigations into allegations of a sexual nature to be initiated and concluded with a month of being reported; that investigations be transparent; that complainants be informed of any penalties imposed, and that any offences be permanently recorded by the institution.
attributes.additional_details:
The current University rape culture needs to be addressed immediately, with greater urgency. I want the Government to implement a statutory procedure universities are required to follow when dealing with incidents of a sexual nature, that is consistent across all Universities.
 
Currently Universities are by no means an environment that students feel safe in. This is due to the lack of consequence for sexual assault allegations. Sexual assault cases rarely result in expulsion, meaning many victims are forced to see their abuser around campus. A statutory process should improve outcomes for victims.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Ban Animal Products
attributes.background: We, the undersigned, believe that the government should and must cut all subsidies to animal farming and ban the sale, export and consumption of animal products including but not limited to: flesh, eggs, dairy, honey, leather, wool, fur, down.
attributes.additional_details:
The animal agriculture industry causes horrific damage to the environment, humans & non-human animals and to public health. The farming and consumption of animal products has been linked to health crises including vCJD, avian flu and antimicrobial resistance.
It is one of the biggest sources of GHGs and environmental destruction.
Animals live in brutal conditions in UK factory farms and die in pain & fear years before their natural life expectancy.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban counselling notes of rape survivors from being used in court
attributes.background: Victims of rape and sexual assault are discouraged from having counselling because of the fear that their counselling notes could be used against them if their case goes to court.
attributes.additional_details: Victims of rape and sexual assault should be able to speak freely in a safe environment without the worry of potential repercussions to their case. Only 15% of those who experience sexual violence report it to the police because of the lack of help and support. This means that other citizens are still in danger from unreported rapists and the victim is living in fear of another assault.

departments.name: Ministry of Justice

attributes.action: Ban plastic wrapping of individual items of fruit or vegetables
attributes.background: Ban supermarkets from selling plastic wrapped individual items of fruit or vegetables - there is a huge environmental risk posed by this type of single use plastic, especially as most councils across the UK do not recycle it and so it ends up in landfill, or even worse, our environment.
attributes.additional_details: Ban supermarkets from selling plastic wrapped individual items of fruit or vegetables - there is a huge environmental risk posed by this type of single use plastic, especially as most councils across the UK do not recycle it and so it ends up in landfill, or even worse, our environment.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Legally Require All Meat Packaging to Show Slaughter Images
attributes.background: There are now at least half a million vegans in the UK. The UK claim to be a nation of animal lovers, but most people continue to eat and enjoy meat knowing full well that animals are killed for meat. Because of this, billions of land and marine animals are killed each year in the UK.
attributes.additional_details:
The truth is that all animal slaughter involves cruelty and death. In the UK, pigs are still being gassed, and animals are killed by throat-cutting.

Putting images of slaughter on meat packaging could help reduce meat sales, help save the environment and help save more animals!

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban third party sales of rabbits in England.
attributes.background: The Government should ban third party sales of rabbits in England (i.e. pet shops) & require people to buy direct from a licensed breeder or adopt from a rescue centre instead. Licensed breeders will be required to show the rabbit's birth certificate & meet certain licence conditions.
attributes.additional_details: This should reduce the number of rabbits who are sick, traumatised & unsocialised due to low-welfare breeding & selling environments, as well as meet the requirements of the Animal Welfare Act 2006, which states that animals should have a “suitable environment” and “be able to exhibit normal behaviour patterns”. Research has shown there are prevalent welfare issues in the UK pet rabbit industry & banning third party sellers should make rabbit breeders more accountable.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Introduce a levy on single-use disposable plastic
attributes.background:
I want the UK Government and Parliament to introduce a levy on single-use disposable plastic manufactured and sold in the UK.

This will help consumers, business and industry transition towards more sustainable solutions; ones that are long term and ones that consider the entire product lifecycle.
attributes.additional_details:
The impact of plastic pollution on our natural environment isn’t just a problem for the UK. It’s a global one. 

In 2021 the UK will host COP26 and the G7. Whilst SARS-CoV-2 (COVID19) will dominate the conversation, the UK must use these events to tackle plastic pollution as well as climate change and the effect it will have on our natural environment. 

This levy may create a fund for research into the effects of plastic pollution as well as solutions that may lead to an outright ban.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Allow deaths to be registered remotely
attributes.background: We want the Government to allow deaths to be registered in line with the temporary provisions of the Coronavirus Act 2020, which allowed deaths to be registered remotely, medical practitioners to sign death certificates without having attended the deceased, and documents be submitted electronically
attributes.additional_details:
We believe this would be a more efficient, cost effective, modern approach, and would:

- Benefit bereaved families by allowing them to register a death remotely without a physical appointment.
- Create opportunities for registrars to work from home should the need arise
- Reduce restrictions on completing documentation associated with a death
- Reduce the impact on the environment (reducing the need to travel to appointments)

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Lift social distancing in schools and nurseries for the sake of mental health
attributes.background: We would like the government to lift all social distancing measures in schools, so children can go back to their normal activities. Any future measures on schools related to Covid19 should be presented to parliament for voting considering the mental health, social and educational needs of children.
attributes.additional_details: Schools and nurseries are environments where children develop social skills that are essential to life in society. Social distancing measures do not allow for these aspects to be fomented. As staff needs to concentrate on excessive disinfection, and access to material such as toys and books is limited, the focus is taken away from teaching. Engagement between parents and teachers is also reduced, as well as pupils' motivation to go back to school. All of these could impact mental health negatively.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Do not reduce environmental protections or protected species legislation
attributes.background: During a recent speech from PM he said "the newt-counting delays in our system are a massive drag on the productivity and prosperity of this country" This is worrying, it sounds like he wants to remove protected species legislation and this could lead to degrading of environmental protection laws.
attributes.additional_details:
Great crested newts are a protected species, their numbers are declining. Currently they are protected through Annex II and IV of the EU habitats directive.

As the UK recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic we should lead the way for a green revolution for the environment and economy.
 
The Government should clarify whether it has any plans to remove protected species legislation for newts, which could lead to a further removal of environmental protections in this country and is the opposite of what is needed now.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Implement a Deposit Return Scheme for glass and plastic in 2021
attributes.background:
The Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs has been consulting on the implementation of a Deposit Return Scheme for glass and plastic.
Such a scheme is not currently expected to go live until 2023.
The Government should accelerate the implementation and bring it forward to 2021.
attributes.additional_details:
This year people have left mounds of rubbish at public spaces and beauty spots across the UK and beyond.

Many studies have reported the presence of microplastics not only in our oceans but also in treated tap and bottled water. This raises questions and concerns about the impact that polluted drinking-water has on human health.

More recently, microplastic pollution has been found to cause significant damage to organisms in the soil, adversely affecting ecology and soil fertility.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase penalties for illegal off-road driving
attributes.background: Penalties for illegal off-road driving should be increased, with greater minimum sentences/fines and vehicle confiscation, to deter the huge increase in recreational off-road vehicle usage on grazing/common land which is damaging the livestock, our wildlife, environment and rural communities.
attributes.additional_details: Local wildlife, farmers, communities have relied on moorlands for generations and these vital peatlands are under threat with livestock unable to graze safely now. These illegal, vehicle users are shredding moorland to pieces. This problem has grown over the years and the increase is mainly adults using our moorland to exercise off-road bikes/4x4s and has now reached an overwhelming level. The huge increase in this illegal activity is damaging breeding grounds and the environment to a huge level.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Keep all schools and colleges open in England
attributes.background:
To ensure schools and colleges are kept open in a Covid-secure environment with extra measures in place, will positively impact on education and also the mental health and wellbeing of pupils and parents.
We need to ensure this generation of young people are allowed access to face to face teaching.
attributes.additional_details: Many children and young people have experienced loneliness during lockdown and have also been affected by lack of physical contact with their friends, families and peers. 41% of children reported feeling more stressed about schoolwork and exams since schools closed. Children in England are three months behind in their studies after lockdown, suggests a survey of teachers by an educational research organisation. The Government has said that children must not lose out because of coronavirus.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Create a ‘Homes for Afghanistan’ refugee scheme
attributes.background: As of December, around 12,000 Afghan refugees brought over by Operation Warm Welcome remain stuck in hotels around the UK. Given the huge response to Homes for Ukraine and the British public's concern for Afghans in danger from the Taliban, it makes sense to create a similar scheme for them too.
attributes.additional_details: Keeping Afghans in hotels is costing £1.2m a day. Hotel rooms aren't suitable for long-term accommodation for traumatised people fleeing persecution, and are a particularly challenging environment for families with children. The Resettlement Scheme seems to have stalled - having only resettled around 4,000 refugees as of early Feb. There remain many in Afghanistan who, although not having worked directly with British forces, are in danger as they worked for humanitarian organisations e.g. British charities, who are now targeted by the Taliban. To ensure immigration control and security, those offering homes under a ‘Homes for Afghanistan’ scheme could be invited to identify particular persons whom they wish to sponsor who can then be vetted, as with the ‘Homes for Ukraine’ scheme.

departments.name: Home Office

attributes.action: Reform school behaviour policies to prioritise wellbeing and inclusion
attributes.background: We want the Government to recognise the need for a system-wide review and redevelopment of school behaviour policies, support and training, to benefit young people in schools; aiming to complement and extend the DfE guidance on supporting emotional wellbeing and inclusion.
attributes.additional_details: To be able to learn, all children need to feel safe, in a calm, orderly positive environment. More than ever, all children, young people and adults in schools, especially the most vulnerable, will need support to recover their sense of well-being, following the COVID-19 pandemic. Developing systems of behaviour management that are relational, empathetic and aim to understand conduct through the lens of a child’s prior experiences, will rebuild trusting relationships in order that they thrive.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Create a new Bank Holiday in recognition of the NHS and all its amazing workers.
attributes.background: I would love to see the government create a new public Bank Holiday - NHS Appreciation Day - to acknowledge all workers affiliated with the NHS.
attributes.additional_details: In the adverse times that we face as a nation, NHS workers are the front-line individuals, keeping us safe and working hard to treat and save our sick in the most testing of environments. They are putting their own health at risk and are working tirelessly, away from their family and friends. When this crisis is over, we simply must find a way to express our appreciation in a celebration of all that they do. A Bank Holiday would be a time for the nation to raise up these amazing individuals.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Require driving instructors and students to wear face masks during lessons
attributes.background: The Government should make face masks mandatory for driving lessons and advise instructors to ensure good ventilation at all times. Face masks are required on public transport, where people are in larger environments, but not for instructors or their students in smaller vehicles who sit closer.
attributes.additional_details: The DVSA insist on face masks for tests but this requirement does not extend to lessons. There are 40,000 instructors who teach up to 10 pupils per day. Many are not wearing masks and have windows closed using air conditioning. The age group of students is 17+ and many are leading normal lives and not respecting social distancing. The lack of requirement for using face masks puts driving instructors, students and their families at risk.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Require clear labelling on all products linked to deforestation.
attributes.background: Require by law that all products display an immediately visible symbol, showing any links to deforestation. This will allow the public to make fully informed buying choices to actively prevent the climate crisis worsening.
attributes.additional_details: If current trends continue, more than a quarter of the Amazon biome will be without trees by 2030 (WWF), further accelerating the climate crisis. The Environment Bill introduced on 10th November requires due diligence on sourcing standards, but does not inform UK citizens of the consequences of their choices at purchase points. Clear labelling on products will allow the public to quickly identify and avoid products and services linked to deforestation.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Include the impact of fast fashion on the curriculum
attributes.background: Change the curriculum to include the environmental impact of fast fashion. In  lessons children should be taught the importance of repairing instead of re-buying and be educated on the air miles, water consumption and human suffering put into fast fashion.
attributes.additional_details: The Conservative Manifesto promises they will "crack down on the waste and carelessness that destroys our environment" as well as tackles plastic pollution "both in the UK and internationally." Currently the fashion industry accounts for around 20% of wastewater and 10% of Co2 emissions. Change starts with education, therefore in order to live up to these promises, changes to the curriculum must be made.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Hold a referendum to decide if the UK should commit to Carbon Neutrality by 2030
attributes.background: We are asking that the government hold a national referendum to ask whether or not the UK should bring forward its target of net-neutrality to 2030. This may follow a similar framework as the 2050 target. The referendum would set the option of having neutrality by 2030 or keeping the current target.
attributes.additional_details: While a referendum is not legally binding, a large proportion of our country in favour of net neutrality would demonstrate that the government's priorities should lay with protecting the environment and halting climate change. Our current target for 2050 is a valuable step, but the sentiment behind the target will be futile if we don't achieve net neutrality sooner. We aren't asking for an immediate commitment - we are simply asking that the question is put to the nation to decide.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Amnesty for undocumented migrants after 5 years and ILR after 14 Years
attributes.background: Regularise undocumented migrants, who have been in the UK for 5 years or more and reduce the number of years a person has to be resident in the UK to be entitled to Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR) under long residence rules from 20 to 14 years.
attributes.additional_details:
Granting an amnesty and making it easier to gain leave to remain should help end the suffering of many undocumented migrants currently living in the UK. This would mean many would be free of the hostile environment and able to rent housing, access healthcare and public funds.
 
Granting an amnesty to undocumented migrants in the UK should help end suffering for many undocumented migrants, many of whom are undocumented through no fault of their own.

departments.name: Home Office

attributes.action: Amend the Bus Services Act 2017 to allow public ownership of bus companies
attributes.background: We would like the Government to revoke section 22 of the Bus Services Act 2017, which forbids any local transport authority from forming a new municipal bus company.
attributes.additional_details:
We firmly believe that by allowing local authorities to take control of local passenger services it will vastly improve services for the public.
We believe that private companies have put profit ahead of running a reliable service and more and more rural areas are losing services that are vital to the community because of this, moving to public ownership can change this.
Public ownership could also help the environment as private companies are sometimes reluctant to embrace cleaner buses unless financially motivated to do so.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Lower tuition fees to a minimum £5,000 for University students during covid-19.
attributes.background: Frankly, university students aren’t getting the education they were promised when they chose to go to university through such a tough year, as well as those in 2nd or 3rd years who have had their learning environment completely changed.
attributes.additional_details: We need change and we need a reduction in the fees that aren’t justified. The definition of tuition fees, as seen on the UCAS website, is: “Tuition fees are charged by universities and colleges to cover key elements of your course and academic life, as well as core services related to students’ wellbeing and experience on campus”. No one can say that this definition is being met this year.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Allow Grassroots football to keep going for juniors
attributes.background: Please reconsider the judgement on the new lockdown rules and allow individuals sports to carry on for juniors such as grass routes football. The sport is vital for individuals physical and mental health save a generation of sport and keep grass routes alive
attributes.additional_details: Allow the grass routes football to carry on within a safe and secure covid environment. Sport especially football is a vital aspect of children’s everyday life without sport a child’s physical and mental health will suffer. Sport is a powerful tool which gives individuals a sense of confidence be also opportunities to participate in sport and over come physical and mental barriers. Keep the sports going at grass routes level and give the kids hope

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Introduce a 'litter tax' on all single-use packaging
attributes.background: A sales tax should be imposed on all products whose packaging can only be used once, such as drinks cans and plastic wrappers. The revenue should then be used to help clean up the environment and prevent plastics and other items getting into rivers and oceans.
attributes.additional_details:
This work could create job opportunities for those who are out of work. The public should be told why a litter tax is needed, as a consequence of irresponsible behaviour.

I think this could help make our country less untidy. In other countries litter is hardly seen due to apparent better social behaviour and better methods to keep fields and roadsides clean. Look at any roadside or motorway verge, and see the levels of non-stop rubbish discarded. These items get into stream and rivers, and make our roads, towns and countryside so shabby. Use the revenue generated to create jobs and clean the country up.
